title: SSO Integration
description: Implement SAML/OIDC-based single sign-on for enterprise customers — sales has three deals pending on this, so no pressure.

outcomes.clear_success: SSO is live and three deals close within 30 days; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: OIDC works but SAML attribute mapping is still manual per client and sales stops complaining in steering meetings; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: SSO exposed a critical session-management flaw and forced an auth refactor; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: SSO is functional but admin UX is confusing enough to require a two-hour setup call per customer; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A SAML metadata config error provisioned all users at one customer as admins; legal wants a meeting.

title: SCIM User Provisioning
description: Build a SCIM 2.0 endpoint for automated user provisioning and deprovisioning — three late-stage prospects are literally waiting.

outcomes.clear_success: SCIM launched and all three pending enterprise deals closed in month one; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: SCIM works but attribute mapping is manual — two deals move forward anyway; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: SCIM exposed inconsistencies between roles and permissions nobody knew existed; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: SCIM is live but only one customer deploys it; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: A race condition left 300 deprovisioned users active; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Role-Based Access Control
description: Design and implement granular role-based permissions (admin, viewer, editor, auditor, plus custom roles) so access control stops being a spreadsheet.

outcomes.clear_success: RBAC is live with predefined roles and a custom builder; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Predefined roles work but custom roles need engineering help, so customers adapt their orgs to our model; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The permission schema created edge cases with inheritance and delegation; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: RBAC works but the admin UI is cluttered — customers email support about permission-denied errors that each take 30 minutes to diagnose; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A role inheritance bug granted unintended permissions to 12% of users at a large customer; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Comprehensive Audit Logging
description: Implement detailed audit logs for all entity changes, with filtering, export, and tamper-proof storage.

outcomes.clear_success: Audit logs are comprehensive and immutable; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: Most changes are logged but custom integrations are not — auditors noted the gap; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Audit log storage grew faster than anyone projected and we had to compress retroactively; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Audit logs work but search and filtering are painfully slow on large datasets; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A retention misconfig deleted logs that were supposed to be immutable; update your resume.

title: Custom Branding & White-Label
description: Allow enterprise customers to customize UI colors, logos, email templates, and domain branding so it looks like they built it themselves.

outcomes.clear_success: White-label branding shipped and both prospects converted; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: UI rebranding works but emails and embedded widgets still show our logo; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Brand customization multiplied UI variants and visual regression testing became a weekly ritual; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Branding works but requires engineering per customer to wire custom CSS; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A caching issue served one customer's branding to another for six hours; legal wants a meeting.

title: Data Residency Compliance
description: Support data residency requirements so customer data stays within specific geographic regions (EU, US, APAC) — because sovereignty is not optional.

outcomes.clear_success: Data residency is configurable at onboarding; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: Residency works for primary databases but analytics still run on shared infra — the DACH customer accepted a compliance addendum; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Residency added latency to cross-region operations; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: Residency is implemented but region selection is unclear — three customers picked the wrong one; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: Replication lag corrupted the EU backup during a failover test, and recovery required seven-day-old snapshots; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Enterprise SLA Dashboard
description: Build a customer-facing dashboard showing uptime, incident response times, and SLA metrics in real-time — the transparency no one asked for until procurement did.

outcomes.clear_success: SLA dashboard launched with real-time uptime and response times; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: The dashboard exists but calculations are still manual and update every 24 hours; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The dashboard showed tickets closing in 18 hours against a 12-hour SLA; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: The dashboard works but the visuals confuse everyone; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A calculation error reported 99.98% uptime during 47 minutes of downtime; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Enterprise Admin Console
description: Build a dedicated admin portal for enterprise customers to manage users, audit logs, integrations, and security settings from one place instead of six.

outcomes.clear_success: Admin console launched with all promised features and enterprise customers moved workflows into it within weeks; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: The console covers about 70% of use cases; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The console got so feature-rich that customers asked for API access to automate console actions; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: The console shipped but the IA is confusing and customers click through nested menus to find basic settings; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A permission bug let lower admins view and modify restricted settings; update your resume.

title: Bulk User Management
description: Enable bulk import and export of users, data, and configs via CSV and API so enterprise onboarding doesn't require a full-time coordinator.

outcomes.clear_success: Bulk import is live and enterprises onboard hundreds of users in minutes instead of hours; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Bulk import works for basic creation but custom attributes still need manual entry — helpful, not fully self-serve; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Bulk import exposed customer data quality issues; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Bulk import is sound but gives no feedback until completion; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A race condition processed the same CSV twice, creating 4,000 duplicate users; legal wants a meeting.

title: Custom API Rate Limits
description: Let enterprise customers request higher API rate limits with monitoring and alerts, because apparently the default limits are 'insulting.'

outcomes.clear_success: Custom rate limits are live and the scaling customer hits targets without throttling; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Custom limits work but require manual provisioning per customer; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Higher limits exposed wildly inefficient API usage — instead of optimizing, the customer asked for even higher limits; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Custom limits exist but the customer did not know they could request them; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A calculation error set one customer's limit 100x too high; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Dedicated Support Portal
description: Build a customer-facing portal where enterprise customers can submit, track, and escalate support tickets without emailing anyone.

outcomes.clear_success: Support portal launched with ticket tracking and SLA transparency; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: The portal works for basic submissions but escalation paths are still manual — complex issues route inconsistently; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The portal exposed response-time differences by customer size; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: The portal exists but adoption is low; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A sync error marked resolved tickets as awaiting customer response for weeks; update your resume.

title: SOC 2 Compliance Mode
description: Implement compliance features for SOC 2 Type II attestation — audit trails, access controls, the works — because enterprise deals die in procurement.

outcomes.clear_success: SOC 2 Mode is live and verified by external auditors; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Most requirements are met but immutable logging carries performance tradeoffs; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Compliance infrastructure is expensive to maintain; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: SOC 2 Mode is implemented but documentation is thin; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: Auditors found that immutable logs were being deleted by retention; legal wants a meeting.

title: HIPAA Compliance Features
description: Build HIPAA-required features: PHI encryption, access logging, retention policies, and breach notification, because healthcare customers do not negotiate on compliance.

outcomes.clear_success: HIPAA features are live and verified by the customer's compliance team; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: Requirements are mostly met, but BAAs and ongoing training are mandatory; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: HIPAA constraints spread across the codebase and features that were simple now need PHI guardrails; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: HIPAA features shipped but the customer's audit found gaps; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: A data export included PHI in an unencrypted CSV and the customer's breach notification mentioned our platform; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Custom Reporting Engine
description: Build flexible reporting allowing enterprise customers to create custom dashboards and exports without engineering support.

outcomes.clear_success: Reporting engine is live and enterprise customers build custom reports in hours instead of weeks; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Common use cases are covered, but complex multi-table queries still require engineering and customers like the foundation; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Some customers built monster queries that caused performance issues; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: The UI is powerful but overwhelming and customers use a small fraction of capabilities; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A SQL injection vulnerability let a customer extract data they did not have permission to view; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Advanced Permission Model
description: Implement end-to-end encryption for data at rest and in transit — because 'we take security seriously' should mean something.

outcomes.clear_success: Advanced permissions are live and the large customer deploys complex structures that match their org; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: Most scenarios work but some delegation patterns need manual configuration and the customer adapts their org to the system; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Permission evaluation adds latency to every request; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Advanced permissions are implemented but the UI is complex and customers need training; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A caching bug left a removed user with permissions for 72 hours; update your resume.

title: Multi-Tenancy Isolation
description: Isolate enterprise tenants with guaranteed data separation, separate rate limits, and independent compliance posture.

outcomes.clear_success: Multi-tenancy shipped with guaranteed isolation and the financial services customer provisions three business units; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Multi-tenancy works but analytics and backups still share infrastructure; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Tenant-aware changes touched the entire platform — every feature now needs tenant context; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Multi-tenancy is implemented but a search bug briefly showed tenant A's users in tenant B's results — the customer spotted it immediately; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A backup restore loaded all tenant data into a single tenant; legal wants a meeting.

title: Contract Management Integration
description: Support real-time streaming via webhooks and server-sent events so enterprise integrations can stop polling us every 30 seconds.

outcomes.clear_success: Contract data synced from Salesforce and renewal alerts fire 90 days out; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: Integration works but amendments do not sync automatically and sales updates records manually after changes; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Salesforce data is stale by 2-3 days, so alerts occasionally fire at the wrong time; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: Contract data is integrated but not prominent and sales keeps using Salesforce as the source of truth; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: A sync error shifted contract end dates by 30 days for 18 customers; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Custom Data Retention
description: Let enterprise customers define custom data retention policies (delete or archive after N days) so their legal teams can sleep at night.

outcomes.clear_success: Custom retention policies are live; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Policies work but edge cases like child records need manual handling and the customer adapts; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Retention jobs at scale took longer than expected and hammered the database; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Policies are available but the UI is confusing and customers ask support to configure them; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A retention bug applied policies in reverse: temporary data kept forever and important data deleted; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Enterprise Onboarding Wizard
description: Build a guided, multi-step onboarding wizard for enterprise customers covering setup, provisioning, and integration config — handholding, but make it scalable.

outcomes.clear_success: The onboarding wizard is live; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: The wizard covers basic setup but complex integrations still need professional services and onboarding drops to 2-3 weeks; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The wizard makes choices that customers later want to undo; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: The wizard works but abandonment is high; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: The integration step connected to customer systems using generic credentials; update your resume.

title: Sandbox Environments
description: Provide customers with isolated sandbox instances for testing and development before deploying to production.

outcomes.clear_success: Sandboxes are available and enterprise customers clone production to test integrations safely; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: Sandboxes work but cloning takes four hours and needs manual credential rotation; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Support requests for sandboxes became common; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: Sandboxes exist but provisioning is not self-serve; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: A cloning bug included a live production API key in a sandbox and the customer revoked it; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Approval Workflows
description: Implement configurable approval workflows for sensitive operations (data export, user access grants, contract changes).

outcomes.clear_success: Approval workflows are live and enterprise customers configure multi-stage approvals for sensitive operations; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Basic approvals work but escalation logic is manual — complex chains still require intervention; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Approval workflows add friction everywhere — tasks that took minutes now take hours; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Workflows exist but notifications are unreliable — approvers miss requests, so we fell back to email; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A state-machine bug left requests stuck in pending indefinitely; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Enterprise Support SLA Tiers
description: Define tiered support SLAs for enterprise customers (critical: 1hr, high: 4hr, normal: 24hr) so expectations are contractual instead of aspirational.

outcomes.clear_success: SLA tiers are live and sales closes deals at three price points; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: SLA tiers are defined but critical response times are missed 12% of the time due to staffing gaps; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Support burns out trying to meet critical SLAs; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: SLA tiers exist but tracking lives in a manual spreadsheet with low transparency; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A data entry error assigned a normal-tier customer to the critical SLA; update your resume.

title: Security Questionnaire Export
description: Generate a standard security questionnaire export (hosting, encryption, access controls) for procurement reviews.

outcomes.clear_success: Questionnaire export shipped and procurement cycles shrink by weeks; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Export works but uses last quarter's wording and sales sends it anyway; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Security teams treat the export as the official source of truth; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Procurement wanted a spreadsheet, not a PDF; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: The export claims encryption coverage we do not have and a prospect flags the gap; legal wants a meeting.

title: Advanced Audit Logging
description: Build comprehensive audit logging for all user actions with tamper-proof storage — enterprise compliance teams live for this stuff.

outcomes.clear_success: Audit logging shipped and security questionnaires suddenly have more green checkmarks; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Logging works for core actions but edge cases are missing and we document those as known gaps; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Audit logs revealed internal admin actions that look suspicious to compliance teams; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Logging infrastructure exists but queries are slow and nobody uses it; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: Log storage filled the database and brought the system down for 90 minutes; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Role-Based Access Control v2
description: Current RBAC is binary (admin or user) — enterprise customers need granular permissions with custom roles and inheritance.

outcomes.clear_success: RBAC v2 shipped with custom roles and enterprise deals close faster; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Custom roles work but role inheritance is buggy and enterprise admins work around it; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Granular permissions exposed gaps in the UI and users can configure roles that look valid but do nothing; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: RBAC is powerful but so complex that customers request training sessions; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A permission inheritance bug granted admin rights to regular users for 6 hours; legal wants a meeting.

title: Multi-Region Data Residency
description: Enterprise customers in the EU and APAC need data stored in-region for compliance — AWS bills are about to get interesting.

outcomes.clear_success: Multi-region deployed and European deals that stalled for months suddenly close; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: EU and US regions live; APAC delayed but we sell it anyway; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Regional data residency exposed latency issues when services cross regions and performance regressed; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Infrastructure exists but data replication is unreliable and manual intervention is common; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A replication bug leaked EU customer data to US servers; this becomes a quarterly lesson.
